<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Millions of kids are heading back to school right now and you can help us fund their classroom projects. More on that below...</span></li>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TOBACCO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/08/27/big-tobacco-wants-cool-vape?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Big Tobacco Wants to Be Cool and Vape, Too
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Big Tobacco Wants to Be Cool and Vape, Too" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTY2OTM5NDcyLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After 11 years apart, Altria (-3.99%) and Philip Morris International (PMI) are weighing an all-stock <a href="https://apnews.com/ba8a0d4c773c4bc89d5f21eac9d887d3?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">merger of equals</a> that would create a $200 billion-plus tobacco, e-cig, and everything-in-between giant. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">PMI (-7.76%) served as Altria's international unit until it was spun off in 2008, leaving Altria to focus primarily on the U.S. market (the two share the same portfolio of cigarettes, including Marlboro). But a decade of efforts by regulators and health officials to curb smoking + the meteoric rise of e-cigarettes and vaping has taken its toll. Now, the companies are considering a reunion.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Together at last </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After some awkward small talk at their favorite diner, Altria decided to tell PMI what it’s been up to these last few years.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Last December, Altria </span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-cronos-group-m-a-altria-group/altria-to-marry-pot-with-big-tobacco-in-1-8-billion-cronos-deal-idUSKBN1O61BS?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">invested</a></span><span> $1.8 billion in Canadian cannabis producer Cronos Group for a 45% stake. On the same day, it said it would discontinue several e-cig brands. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Here's why: </strong></span><span>Later that month, Altria </span><span><a href="https://www.npr.org/2018/12/20/678915071/altria-buys-35-percent-stake-in-e-cigarette-maker-juul?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">paid</a></span><span> $12.8 billion to acquire a 35% stake in Juul, the leading U.S. e-cigarette manufacturer that's become popular among middle schoolers and, subsequently, concerned lawmakers. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">PMI, meanwhile, has sunk billions into developing IQOS—a cigarette alternative that doesn't burn tobacco—as it shifts to "<a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/philip-morris-altria-discussing-all-stock-merger-of-equals-11566913969?mod=hp_lead_pos1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">a smoke-free future</a>." It's already selling the device in 48 international markets. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>PMI has stayed away from cannabis, and its CEO has criticized Juul's contributions to the underage vaping epidemic. So no word yet on whether the kids will get along. </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Those synergies tho</h2>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Altria's expanded Juul across the U.S., but Juul's international footprint has lagged. PMI has the foreign connections that could come in handy, </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2019/08/27/philip-morris-international-confirms-its-in-merger-talks-with-altria.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">CNBC says</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In turn, Altria could help PMI sell IQOS in the U.S. The device received FDA approval this spring and, under a standing partnership, Altria will license IQOS for the U.S. market. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>As all of you going back to school know, smoking's out, vaping and weed are in. Altria and PMI are trying to get ahead in markets that are expected to be worth tens of billions in the next few years. TBD whether the deal will actually happen, though. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we're here:</strong> North Carolina is <a href="https://www.npr.org/2019/08/27/754717176/north-carolina-says-it-is-suing-8-e-cigarette-companies?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">suing</a> eight e-cigarette companies for illegally marketing vaping products to underage users. It already filed a lawsuit against Juul.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BIZ LAW
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/08/27/levandowski-charged-theft-selfdriving-trade-secrets?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Good Luck Steering out of This One, Levandowski
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Good Luck Steering out of This One, Levandowski" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=447 src="https://morningbrew-oslo.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/1566937678.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Good Luck Steering out of This One, Levandowski" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://morningbrew-oslo.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/1566937678.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Tuesday, federal prosecutors <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/27/technology/google-trade-secrets-levandowski.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">charged</a> Anthony Levandowski, a prominent self-driving technology developer, with 33 counts of trade secret theft. It's the latest twist in the biggest Silicon Valley scandal since Evan Spiegel was caught sending an Instagram story. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If convicted, Levandowski could face up to 10 years and a $250k fine for every charge. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What happened</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Levandowski's accused of <a href="https://www.axios.com/the-full-history-of-the-uber-waymo-legal-fight-1513301467-41102ff0-1642-4209-abf8-a37d0608027c.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">downloading</a> proprietary self-driving tech files before leaving Google in 2016. He joined Uber several months later when it bought Otto, his self-driving truck startup. Waymo, Google's self-driving division, thought, "hmmm that tech looks awfully familiar" and sued Uber.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>In 2017, Uber </span><span><a href="https://www.axios.com/stunner-google-and-uber-settle-1518191623-21a40f85-0a9c-400c-99b6-67282eebd75d.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">settled</a></span><span> with Waymo, promised to never use the secret tech, and handed over almost $245 million in stock. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Levandowski wasn't a defendant in that case, but the judge handed allegations of trade secret theft to prosecutors. You know how that ended. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">A Silicon Valley archetype </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Levandowski's an innovator who pushed self-driving technology years ahead. But besides staring down criminal charges, he's also got his quirks. In 2015, Levandowski <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/god-is-a-bot-and-anthony-levandowski-is-his-messenger/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">founded</a> the "Way of the Future" church to "develop and promote the realization of a Godhead based on artificial intelligence."</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/08/27/economists-eyeing-japanification-stimulate-economy?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
What Everyone's Talking About: Japanification
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some of you are heading to Japan for the Rugby World Cup and 2020 Olympics. We're visiting to better understand what's going on with the global economy.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Starting in the early 1990s, </strong>Japan suffered from low growth, low inflation, and low interest rates. In response, the Bank of Japan pursued <a href="https://think.ing.com/articles/eurozones-japanification-the-long-read/?utm_source=morning_brew#a1?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">unorthodox</a> monetary policy, but it couldn't restart the economic engine. It was like feeding a vending machine that never gave anything back. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some economists, including former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers, see shades of "<a href="https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2019/08/22/the-japanification-of-bond-markets?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Japanification</a>" happening right now in Europe...and maybe even the U.S. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><img src="https://morningbrew-oslo.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/1566948721.jpg" class="img-responsive" width="540" style="width:100% !important;max-width: 540px;" alt=""></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><sup class="sub-text"><a href="https://twitter.com/LHSummers/status/1164490340281344002?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>@LHSummers</em></a></sup></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Here's one example: </strong>Globally, more than $16 trillion worth of bonds, over 30% of the total, trade at below-zero yields, the FT <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/314c626a-c77b-11e9-a1f4-3669401ba76f?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reminds us</a>. (Yes, a sub-zero yield means you are paying someone to hold onto your money.)</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>The prospect of Japanification spreading to other countries is all the rage in the central banker Slack channel. It means their traditional tools for stimulating the economy might not work this time around. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FILM
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/08/27/netflix-bypasses-tradition-limited-theatrical-release-irishman?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Netflix vs. Theater Industry: Take 2
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Netflix vs. Theater Industry: Take 2" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://slack-imgs.com/?c=1&o1=ro&url=https%3A%2F%2Fpbs.twimg.com%2Fmedia%2FEAqH09eVAAAFAKw.jpg">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Netflix</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Netflix has departed from tradition once again after <a href="https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/netflix-forgoes-wide-release-martin-scorseses-irishman-1234382?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">failing to reach</a> an agreement with exhibitors for a wide theatrical release of Martin Scorsese's <em>The Irishman</em>. The streamer will release the gangster epic in select indie theaters starting Nov. 1 before it hits your Netflix homepage Nov. 27. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Theater owners think this is a bunch of raging bull.</strong> They're used to operating under an "exclusivity window," which gives them a three-month grace period to show films before the movies are released on other platforms. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Netflix has turned Hollywood into a casino as it moves aggressively into the film industry. Last year, it released the critically acclaimed <em>Roma </em>in theaters for around three weeks before making it available to subscribers. Some industry watchers <a href="https://www.indiewire.com/2019/02/roma-netflix-backlash-best-picture-alfonso-cuaron-responds-1202047807/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said</a> <em>Roma </em>could have won Best Picture if Netflix had been a goodfella and gave theaters more time to show the film. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Mark your calendars, gangs of NY: </strong><em>The Irishman</em>'s global release will take place at the New York Film Festival Sept. 27. </p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/08/27/costcos-china-grand-opening-overwhelmed-customers?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Costco to Customers: "Please Don't Come"
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<img alt="No Alt" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Hu Xijin via Twitter</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Costco opened, then promptly closed, its first location in China yesterday after it became overcrowded with customers. The line to enter the parking lot stretched <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2019/08/27/business/costco-shanghai-china-store/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">up to three hours</a>—we wouldn't even wait that long for taquito samples. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a text message alert to customers, Costco wrote, "To provide you with better shopping experience, Costco will suspend business in the afternoon. Please don't come."</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>The pictures above were tweeted by the prominent editor-in-chief of the Global Times, a newspaper controlled by China's Communist Party. As you can tell, he described the store's opening through the lens of the U.S.-China rift. </p>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nTOBACCO\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nBig Tobacco Wants to Be Cool and Vape, Too\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Big Tobacco Wants to Be Cool and Vape, Too\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTY2OTM5NDcyLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAfter 11 years apart, Altria (-3.99%) and Philip Morris International (PMI) are weighing an all-stock \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/ba8a0d4c773c4bc89d5f21eac9d887d3?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emerger of equals\u003c/a\u003e that would create a $200 billion-plus tobacco, e-cig, and everything-in-between giant. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePMI (-7.76%) served as Altria's international unit until it was spun off in 2008, leaving Altria to focus primarily on the U.S. market (the two share the same portfolio of cigarettes, including Marlboro). But a decade of efforts by regulators and health officials to curb smoking + the meteoric rise of e-cigarettes and vaping has taken its toll. Now, the companies are considering a reunion.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eTogether at last \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAfter some awkward small talk at their favorite diner, Altria decided to tell PMI what it’s been up to these last few years.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eLast December, Altria \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-cronos-group-m-a-altria-group/altria-to-marry-pot-with-big-tobacco-in-1-8-billion-cronos-deal-idUSKBN1O61BS?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einvested\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e $1.8 billion in Canadian cannabis producer Cronos Group for a 45% stake. On the same day, it said it would discontinue several e-cig brands. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHere's why: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eLater that month, Altria \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2018/12/20/678915071/altria-buys-35-percent-stake-in-e-cigarette-maker-juul?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epaid\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e $12.8 billion to acquire a 35% stake in Juul, the leading U.S. e-cigarette manufacturer that's become popular among middle schoolers and, subsequently, concerned lawmakers. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePMI, meanwhile, has sunk billions into developing IQOS—a cigarette alternative that doesn't burn tobacco—as it shifts to \"\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/philip-morris-altria-discussing-all-stock-merger-of-equals-11566913969?mod=hp_lead_pos1\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ea smoke-free future\u003c/a\u003e.\" It's already selling the device in 48 international markets. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePMI has stayed away from cannabis, and its CEO has criticized Juul's contributions to the underage vaping epidemic. So no word yet on whether the kids will get along. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThose synergies tho\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAltria's expanded Juul across the U.S., but Juul's international footprint has lagged. PMI has the foreign connections that could come in handy, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2019/08/27/philip-morris-international-confirms-its-in-merger-talks-with-altria.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eCNBC says\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn turn, Altria could help PMI sell IQOS in the U.S. The device received FDA approval this spring and, under a standing partnership, Altria will license IQOS for the U.S. market. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eAs all of you going back to school know, smoking's out, vaping and weed are in. Altria and PMI are trying to get ahead in markets that are expected to be worth tens of billions in the next few years. TBD whether the deal will actually happen, though. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ While we're here:\u003c/strong\u003e North Carolina is \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2019/08/27/754717176/north-carolina-says-it-is-suing-8-e-cigarette-companies?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esuing\u003c/a\u003e eight e-cigarette companies for illegally marketing vaping products to underage users. href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/27/technology/google-trade-secrets-levandowski.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003echarged\u003c/a\u003e Anthony Levandowski, a prominent self-driving technology developer, with 33 counts of trade secret theft. It's the latest twist in the biggest Silicon Valley scandal since Evan Spiegel was caught sending an Instagram story. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf convicted, Levandowski could face up to 10 years and a $250k fine for every charge. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhat happened\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLevandowski's accused of \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/the-full-history-of-the-uber-waymo-legal-fight-1513301467-41102ff0-1642-4209-abf8-a37d0608027c.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edownloading\u003c/a\u003e proprietary self-driving tech files before leaving Google in 2016. He joined Uber several months later when it bought Otto, his self-driving truck startup. Waymo, Google's self-driving division, thought, \"hmmm that tech looks awfully familiar\" and sued Uber.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIn 2017, Uber \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/stunner-google-and-uber-settle-1518191623-21a40f85-0a9c-400c-99b6-67282eebd75d.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esettled\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e with Waymo, promised to never use the secret tech, and handed over almost $245 million in stock. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLevandowski wasn't a defendant in that case, but the judge handed allegations of trade secret theft to prosecutors. You know how that ended. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eA Silicon Valley archetype \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLevandowski's an innovator who pushed self-driving technology years ahead. But besides staring down criminal charges, he's also got his quirks. In 2015, Levandowski \u003ca href=\"https://www.wired.com/story/god-is-a-bot-and-anthony-levandowski-is-his-messenger/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efounded\u003c/a\u003e the \"Way of the Future\" church to \"develop and promote the realization of a Godhead based on Japanification\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSome of you are heading to Japan for the Rugby World Cup and 2020 Olympics. We're visiting to better understand what's going on with the global economy.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eStarting in the early 1990s, \u003c/strong\u003eJapan suffered from low growth, low inflation, and low interest rates. In response, the Bank of Japan pursued \u003ca href=\"https://think.ing.com/articles/eurozones-japanification-the-long-read/?utm_source=morning_brew#a1?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eunorthodox\u003c/a\u003e monetary policy, but it couldn't restart the economic engine. It was like feeding a vending machine that never gave anything back. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSome economists, including former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers, see shades of \"\u003ca href=\"https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2019/08/22/the-japanification-of-bond-markets?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eJapanification\u003c/a\u003e\" happening right now in Europe...and maybe even the U.S. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://morningbrew-oslo.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/1566948721.jpg\" class=\"img-responsive\" width=\"540\" style=\"width:100% !important;max-width: 540px;\" alt=\"\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003csup class=\"sub-text\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/LHSummers/status/1164490340281344002?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e@LHSummers\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHere's one example: \u003c/strong\u003eGlobally, more than $16 trillion worth of bonds, over 30% of the total, trade at below-zero yields, the FT \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/314c626a-c77b-11e9-a1f4-3669401ba76f?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereminds us\u003c/a\u003e. (Yes, a sub-zero yield means you are paying someone to hold onto your money.)\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThe prospect of Japanification spreading to other countries is all the rage in the central banker Slack channel.
